traits.kingship_and_status: Introduced as King Herod ruling in Judea when Jesus is born, functioning as Rome’s client king over the region.
traits.interaction_with_magi: Disturbed by the arrival of magi seeking the newborn king of the Jews, secretly inquires about the star and sends them to Bethlehem under the pretense of worship.
traits.threat_and_violence: On realizing he has been tricked by the magi, orders the massacre of the boys in and around Bethlehem, embodying tyrannical opposition to the promised ruler.
traits.narrative_function: Serves as the political antagonist in Matthew’s infancy narrative, whose actions drive the holy family’s flight to Egypt and fulfill scriptural patterns of threatened deliverers.

traits.chronological_marker: Mentioned as King of Judea in the days when the priest Zechariah receives the announcement of John the Baptist’s birth, anchoring Luke’s infancy story in a specific historical reign.
traits.background_presence: Does not appear as an acting character in Luke’s narrative but serves as part of the political backdrop to the births of John and Jesus.
